parts.text: Hello my name is he sold a car and I'm going to have a conversation with Sherry
Rogers and Mel Moskovitz visible lives and World History Project
at the New York Public Library. Today is May ninth twenty fifteen
and we are interviewing here at the end of high school library in Manhattan.
Sherri tell me a bit about yourself.
Well first of all so thrilled to have this opportunity
. No one has ever taken what it's like to be
blind seriously in my life before and it's just it's wonderful to know
that I can reach out to others this week to tell you
about myself I have noticed pigmentosa I wasn't made aware of it
until I was an adult and it's something that I have
tried very hard not to let define me as a person and yet it's a very
significant part of my life as well.
I don't know when it started.
Why I found out that I officially had R.P. a month
before I married Mel So that was May of one thousand nine hundred eighty four
and it was absolutely devastating news because I had previously
worked as a disability claims examiner for Social Security and I
knew that having R.P. was an automatic
disabling condition.
If you met certain criteria and I knew that it meant I would be going
blind and it just scared the heck out of me. I
was told in a way that was incredibly callous and unfeeling
. My eye doctor
referred me to a neuro ophthalmologist because I told him I had been bumping into
things and he took a very simple peripheral
field test and thought I had a brain tumor but didn't want to say anything
so he referred me to this neuro off them ologist and
the man did his examination handed me a box of tissues and said you have
written itis pigmentosa you're going to go blind and he left the room.
And I just I just didn't know what to do next. I
truly knew what it meant but I didn't know how it could affect my life or that there were
degrees of it or that it could be something that you know eventually there would be
possibly clinical trials for or just research on. I just thought of it
as a as a sentence a visual death. And it really frightened me
and it particularly unnerved me because I now had someone else in my life
that I felt I owed an explanation to and you know he just
he didn't deserve to share this with me without knowing what it was all about
And I couldn't tell him because he didn't know. So that's how I found out.
That's right. Shocking. Yeah I don't recommend it. There must be better ways
Now actually we've been working connected with the Foundation fighting
blindness and we've been working with doctors
who are retina specialists to educate them into how to deal with patients
that they're giving diagnoses to not to hand them a box of tissues and
walk away. But to take the time to explain that you know
this disease has you know it.
It doesn't happen overnight or it might not happen overnight.
There are other retinal diseases there are people who are searching for cures there are people that you can
talk to about it. Don't leave someone sitting in a corner in the dark
because that's what I fear most. Each day I just waited to go blind and I
really didn't know what to do and I think it was like that for almost.
Almost fourteen years until we discovered what condition twenty blindness was
so we really trekked around from retina specialist to retina specialist we
went to Boston. We were very lucky to live here in New York City
But nobody could give me a definition of of what to expect really
. The Internet wasn't as well known as it is now the information
just wasn't out there and so all I had was the ability to tell
my the people closest to me you know I'm I'm going to be having some
problems I don't have them now. But I'm going to need your help and I
think that has been an ongoing problem I have is asking for
help.
Well I'm happy for him.
My parents immediately felt guilty. What did we do Leo
and until we could find out the genetics of it all. We really didn't know
if other cousins were affected so we contacted all my cousins we contacted
my parents siblings the you know the ones who are still living. We couldn't get a good history because
nobody knew much about the people who had died
. Oh well Grandma always wore glasses does that do it you know and we just
said like a rebel for your whole family.
It was it was and cousins were
immediately alarmed and some of them it was interesting some of them chose
not to be tested whatsoever to even have a peripheral field test I
don't know if they were afraid of what they might learn or they were just in a state of
denial and so far among my various cousins
none have exhibited written notice pigmentosa at all. Some
have macular degeneration and some have advanced
glaucoma. Only my dad had written notice
pigmentosa he never knew it and until he died at age ninety
three he was able to retain vision he
stopped driving at night and things like that but nothing nothing that
visually impacted his life in such a negative way.
And so the original researchers we contacted said well you're
probably not going to have any kind of advancement of your disease after all look at your dad
and they were wrong unfortunately. But one of the most amazing
things is dealing with researchers who have compassion
and so we were lucky enough to find someone up in Massachusetts a man named
Elliot person who was able to sit down and talk to
us and he was his colleagues were able to explain what was happening what might
happen what was unlikely to happen. And then ten years later tell
us he was wrong. I guess my R.P. would progress
but that I would still retain some sort of engine. There are other things
happening on the horizon and things I could immediately do to safeguard what was left of my
retina. And you know so you know I became more hopeful and that
really changed my attitude toward life.
So I think you know our grass.
Well how did it progress well I
used to have a measuring stick in a way we have a shower stall in the shower
stall there are various tiles and I would stand with my nose to the corner and see how
many tiles I could see today and I try that
right because I figured OK Oh I should say Britain I just pigmentosa
affects your peripheral vision first and eventually advances into your central vision.
But in my case I had a fairly good
peripheral field at the time that I was diagnosed I continued to drive foolishly
and so I would measure each day and after about six months I think if you know the times
changed much so really this is not the best gauge of you know how my vision is doing
and so I just we live on. I think yearly exams with a retina
specialist and she would do a written of a peripheral fields test and so
she would say things like well turn your head more don't worry about it
and don't take the vitamin a helmeted that was
recommended at that time. Get your get your vitamins through food that's the best
way. And I just didn't buy it because
this was somebody who. Was kind of cavalier about it
all and very nonchalant. And I said if I
don't take the vitamin A The doctor person recommends what do you have to
offer that will nourish my retina. Well we'll find something
in regular food should do it. And so I decided that sometimes retina
specialist don't know all there is to know and it's really a good idea to question them
. And so I started questioning and we were very
fortunate in our family we have a nephew who's an
optometrist and he had heard about the Foundation fighting blindness and he said
why don't you just check this this group out.
And I mean we're not from Mel's nephew. You know I'd really be sitting in the dark
today and truly an isolated and probably much more depressed person
and.
I'd be interested to ask Mel.
What it was like dealing with me for the last fourteen years before we found out but they
all know.
Because of my Yet Yeah.
OK well I'll fill in some of the blanks. I
worked for a company.
As a technical writer. And then I went out and did freelance
work. Which is why I never thought
twice about the driving which was a daily thing.
And then when I would come home I was just so stressed out
. And you know Mel and I would talk about well you know
what was it like how was your day. What did you do. I said I can't even talk I'm
so exhausted and I didn't realize I was so exhausted from trying to focus on getting
everything I could in visually so that I wouldn't hurt myself you know
And eventually it came to the point where I could no longer drive. I could no longer
travel. By car on my own.
And so we had to make a decision as a couple that I would apply for
disability benefits. And it was it was a huge decision because it
was almost two years of constant arguing legal battles
to try and get what I felt was something I rightfully
deserved. One of the things that Mel
suggested I do and I did right away when I started working for a company was to get
long term disability coverage something that I think few people think
about. And it was something that provided me with an income
until I reached the age of sixty six. Had I
not have that I don't know how we would have managed on
on nothing plus no salary which was not as
large as mine at the time. And so when I had to stop working
became you know just incredibly supportive but also
dogging me. Well you didn't contact the lawyer today don't just sit back there and say Oh woe
is me get off your butt. Call the people you have to call write a letter so you
have to write and just do something. Don't just sit there
and I resented him like crazy and he was the best friend I could
possibly have had at that particular moment in my life. And since that
time he's just he's been my both my
protector and my best buddy
and I can't imagine what my life would have been like without him.
We've taken on family together we've taken on the
outside world together we've taken on theaters together. Mel has
been amazing.
He'll take on any group and say you're not doing what you should to
protect people who have visual problems when they come to your theater you see a
restaurant restrooms anything why don't you have these marker
strips Why aren't you putting in hand rails Why aren't you having proper lighting. Why don't you
tell your staff you know how to talk to people who can't see. And he's
marvelous is just. I recommend him highly and I think people should
hire him in that role.
He's getting involved with this line.
Right. Right.
Well it started in one thousand nine hundred ninety eight when we attended a visions
conference in Chicago and it was the first time I've been
here. I was terrified of going what am I going to write all these blind people. You know.
I said well you know what have I got to lose. You know if I can see them and they
can see me how bad off can I be. And if I can see them and they can see me will just
pass one another in the night.
And I go out there and I.
Know it's a terrible phrase it was an eye opening situation it was absolutely
marvelous. It was so life affirming. It was so positive
. I knew. You would hear. From the
researchers which was why we officially went. But then we would break out into
small workshops and you would hear from couples who were dealing with the same
things we were dealing with you would hear from parents who are dealing with
. Raising children who are losing their vision or
parents who had lost their vision trying to raise children who could see you were
dealing with people who had job situations where they were afraid to tell their
employers. You heard human interest stories that are just
absolutely phenomenal and so. Just they run the gamut
. They're so life affirming. There are so. The bravery and
courage of people who are facing something in many cases totally
alone. And in many cases ignorance and
isolation and in communities where there is no
alternative but to drive. Or to sit at home and learning
how they cope and the Foundation fighting blindness gave us the
opportunity to come together. And we started networking groups
and chapters were springing up all over the country. I'm very lucky. We're in a very
large chapter in New York City and we have networking groups and boroughs where
people who don't only have my visual impairment but others as well. I can sit
and talk about what it's like dealing with family what it's like dealing in the workplace
different products that might help us how to look for lighting what to do with certain doctors who don't
respond.
It's just. It's a marvelous organization that.
Prides itself on raising money for research but doesn't have
its. Its secondary goal which is educating the world
on visual impairment on the need for research and the fact
that blind people are for most people and simply not a category
. And so. I. Can't speak them highly enough
I'd love to interview the interviewer here. Is that a possibility. Yeah
. OK.
I'm trying to think since I've left.
The paid employment field I've become much more active
physically socially mentally
. And I've decided that I'm
not going to hide behind my blindness and use it as an excuse not to do things
I've been very active in the women's movement since the early one nine hundred seventy S.
. And my sisters in the movement have a very long way to go as
far as recognizing that people with disabilities also have a great deal to
contribute. Mostly we focus on very dry
and to the public probably very interesting things like changing the
laws and changing minds and hearts about what women can do.
But we don't always think within the women's movement of the gamut of who women are
. It isn't just about who we are
biologically it's who we are as people. And how much of a
role socialization plays in just bringing us into the
world. And so being a female. At a
conference where the pledge of sisterhood is powerful
and being left alone in my room because everyone else said Well meet us at this
restaurant and didn't stop to think well maybe she doesn't know
how to get there.
Made me stop and think and start to work on my sisters in the movement. So the women's
movement in Brooklyn and Queens has been somewhat educated by the blindness factor
. And so now when I go to a place which isn't too often
. I'll say I'd like someone. To meet me there
. I'd like someone to make sure that I'm seated comfortably and if we're ordering food that I know
exactly what's available and come and sit and talk to me don't just leave me
along alone like a bump on a log. Isolation I think is the biggest
problem I faced. When I'm not with people who know
me well. And so it's taken a long time for
family and for casual friends to
recognize that. I need an extra moment of your
time to just include me in things and I can always opt out.
But please include me in unless I say otherwise. And so it's it's
been interesting as the nieces and nephews have grown into adulthood and have children
of their own. The children get it and the parents don't and the
children will say things like how can I get you anything.
Is there something you know that you need or they'll come and sit and talk to me. But the nieces and nephews will
say no just sit there. Don't worry I'll take care of it you don't have to do anything
. And then I'm alone. So it's it's very
interesting.
Well you know what though that way
you know and one of the biggest educators for me at least has been using the
visual cane I was at first very reluctant to use one
but since I was no longer in the employment of being employed
I didn't have to worry about my employer finding out somehow.
And so I could take up my cane and I found out.
Oh I know. Oh absolutely.
When I was working for a brokerage firm it was a very competitive environment
and if I wasn't up to the job surely there would be someone else who was
and so for a long time I was able to do what I needed to do
because I could set the stage for where I would operate. But then as I got

the office or in branch offices or going to
headquarters I found that people not knowing
that I had a vision problem me not acknowledging that I had one resulted
in me falling flat on my face several times when people would leave
just doors open or obstacles in my path that were and
intentionally put their purchases were there or
reports were delayed because the inability I might have had to
produce an entire spreadsheet which could go on for multiple columns when I
could only see maybe two or three columns at a time it would take me longer to produce a
report and so I feared being judged incompetent.
I started to talk to some of my co-workers but never to the higher
ups because I felt that if I asked for any kind of helpful
device and there weren't many at the time maybe larger screens or a little bit
better lighting. I would be seen as somebody
not worth keeping on in the firm. And so
fortunately having the long term disability insurance rates that I've gotten out
here when it becomes impossible for me to do this job and then having Social

have to be able to.
Think that's my that's a signal for my cell phone
I would have. Kind of lost my train of thought
I would have a difficulty.
Knowing that I had Social Security disability benefits that I would eventually become

what they call substantial gainful activity so I would be a

significant drop in income so we went from earning at that time

which was a significant drop. And then you know fortunately we had savings we

within it to be. When you're applying for a
job don't hide behind whatever your disabling
condition might be in the future stated up front and get long term care long term

And some people have taken me up on the option and other people still are very very

It's it's been an interesting development and having the cane

it never fails to touch me you know I always get moved by it.

you know just floors me. You know the song

oh well watch out for that person over there that person has a disabling condition.
